												First off, let me say: I come from a Professor Layton and Ace Attorney background. I live and breathe puzzles, but that's not to say that I'll take whatever I can get. My feelings towards the core factor of the game, puzzles, in Puzzle Agent are a bit mixed, but lean way more towards the positive end than the negative.Let's start with the negative. First off, some puzzle instructions are a bit difficult to understand or are surprisingly vague. However, this only happened to me a few times, and was far from the majority. Secondly, there were some jigsaw puzzles that, if you've played the Professor Layton games, are like the ones where you have to fit items into an area without them overlapping. There are a few here too, but it's odd in pieces automatically click together when placed correctly, and they STAY together, which greatly lessens the challenge. Those puzzles could definitely benefit from a better system, especially one where the general shape of objects were outlined and could snap together even if they weren't placed correctly.Other than that, I found the puzzles enjoyable. A few were quite easy, yes, but others took me a few tries and for some, I had to pull out a good ol' fashioned piece of paper and pen to plot it out Layton-style. Frankly, I don't understand how some people claim to have spent so many hints trying to solve them; I ended up using only 5 or 6 throughout the entire thing. There are 35 puzzles in all - I'll get to that in a moment - with 3 hints per puzzle, so with well over 100 hints you can imagine that 5 is far from a lot. To each their own, I suppose. I've also seen people claim that the puzzles are placed erratically and interrupt the story, but honestly? I've felt that numerable times playing Professor Layton. That is the consequence of puzzle games. They WILL interrupt the story if you choose to do the non-plot-important puzzles, and even some of the necessary ones. That's just how it is. However, especially during the climax of the game, the puzzles begin to weave into the story a bit more cleanly than before, and in my experience, are appropriately some of the easier ones, so you can get through to the ending quicker without having to spend half an hour on one puzzle.I think the game's biggest downfall for me, personally, is LENGTH. It is simply too short. Like I said before, there are only 35 puzzles. The average Professor Layton has over 100. It only took me a few hours to get through the entire game, and it leaves you on a VERY unsatisfying cliffhanger ending. Granted, it does pick up again in the sequel, but it literally goes right from the climax to ending in the first, with practically no conclusion. It was surprising, to say the least. Once the credits popped up I said "that's it?" out loud. I was genuinely surprised.It's a bit cheap to me to separate these two games when it certainly feels like it should be only one, twice-as-long game, but I have no played the second as of yet, so I have no info on how the story of that unfolds or if it is completely related. At the very least, there should be a package including both games so it can be one long, consecutive playthrough without people having to wait until they get money (i.e., me) to finish a story that should have been wrapped up already.The art style, characters, storyline (it's one of the "out there" kind of stories, but it's strangely fun at the same time despite its absurdity), and audio are superb. Music matches the in-game events wonderfully, but don't distract during a puzzle, as it should. I enjoyed the protagonist and the supporting cast, and their voice acting was wonderful as well. I fully recommend this game to new players of puzzle games, or veterans of the Professor Layton series. It may be a bit clunkier than the latter in some respects, but it is definitely worth a good playthrough. You're bound to get some enjoyment out of it.EDIT: Oops, I believe there are actually about 37 puzzles in the game; I had missed two during my first playthrough. Also, I'm going to add that I am currently on my third playthrough of the game, and I still enjoy it. I'm going to add that the game is somewhat fast-paced, or at least the cutscenes are, so even though puzzles will be extraordinarily easy to solve, I'd recommend multiple plays because I've noticed several things that I didn't recognize the first time around, buuut perhaps that was because I was intentionally reading into things because I was analyzing Nelson Tether's character a bit. In any case, definitely worth another look at if you enjoy playing it.One final point I'd like to bring up is that of the somewhat "rating" system assigned to the puzzles. Depending on how many wrong answers you give (resulting in the anger of millions of taxpayers) and how many hints you use, you get assigned a rating of sorts. Perhaps unintentionally, but hilariously, there is some pressure on the player to answer correctly on the first go, so you can expect to unconsciously triple-check your answers before you submit. It's really not something to fret about - at least to me, it's more humorous than anything else.

												Warning: some non-plot related spoilers ahead. Do not read if you want to be completely surprised by the game.Puzzle Agent is a fantastic idea on paper: a hybrid between Joel and Ethan Coen's Fargo and solving puzzles. It is Professor Layton game set in the snowy midwest with plenty of hot dish of "you betcha" remarks added for fun. At first glance, it certainly looks like it will deliver on its promise. While the humor is somewhat subdued (there are no character moments as genuinely funny as the ones found in Fargo) and the story takes its time getting interesting, the art style is appealing and the voice acting is fun. The music is also pitch-perfect, setting the mood to exactly the right type in each scene.But a game like this is ultimately going to succeed or fail based on its puzzles. And that's where Puzzle Agent drops the ball. The puzzle quality and difficulty is all over the place. Some puzzles are clever exercises, such as the fuse box puzzle where players must figure out the correct pattern for the missing fuse and another where players must find the missing gnome on a shelf using an earlier picture negative of the shelf. But others are so simplistic that they belong in a Highlights magazine, such as a riddle about how many socks must be drawn from a drawer to guarantee a match and a "follow the curvy line in a crowd of lines" puzzle). Also boring: several jigsaw-style puzzles where objects automatically snap when they come close to each other, making the challenge negligible. Several puzzles are reused, but luckily, those are usually the more solid (if traditional) puzzles with (somewhat) progressively harder variants.Making things worse is how some classic puzzles are shoehorned into odd themes (at one point, the lead character stumbles on a closed store, leading into a "draw a line from spot to spot without hitting a barrier" puzzle themed as football players practicing while working at a glass store - talk about a stretch). But some puzzles are just downright awful - the worst is probably convoluted puzzle involving fish eating other fish inside that personally took me spending two of my three allowed hints to even understand what the written instructions meant. A close runner-up is a puzzle about using a series of statements to determine who won an arm wrestling tournament - a puzzle that neglects to mention the format of the tournament in posing the question, making it solvable only for those who make that assumption (I'll save players some time: it's a single-elimination event, not a round-robin affair).Even at a low price, I can't really recommend Puzzle Agent. The story is good, but not good enough that it is worth slogging through the puzzles (even if they can be solved very quickly with the ample hints available). As this review should make obvious, it isn't that great for fans of puzzles - a cheap newsstand puzzle magazine has puzzles of better quality. Puzzle Agent is a great idea, but it simply fails to deliver in execution.EDIT: After playing Puzzle Agent 2 (which I purchased at the same time as the first), I would now advise adventure game fans to skip the first one and go straight to the "just good enough to recommend" sequel. Everyone else should probably skip the series entirely.

												Puzzle Agent is an excellent puzzle game.The story follows a detective at the fictional "department of puzzles". It also makes a foray into nordic culture, which I very much enjoyed. There is something intensely creepy about gnomes. The serious nature of detective work, mixed in with comedy makes for a very enjoyable play-through. The gameplay involves either moving around the environment, point&click style, or solving puzzles Professor Layton style. If you've ever played one of those games on the Nintendo DS, you will find the play style very familiar. The environment is easy to move around, it has puzzles hidden in it, and the ui is very intuitive. As for the puzzles, there are 3 main types: Logic, Jigsaw and Grids. The logic and grid puzzles are very good and challenging, and provide a satisfying feeling when completed. The jigsaw puzzles, less so (the pieces just seem to auto-snap together far too easily for my taste).The art in this game is very expressive. I didn't think it possible to show such a range of emotions on the characters, but somehow they pulled it off, from deadpan stares, to sheer terror, to being entranced it all looks very high quality and really adds to immersion and the personality of the characters. The environment also looks very nice, with a very "northern" and cold feeling. As for the sound, the voice acting is all top-notch, as are the various music themes that play throughout.There was one puzzle which bugged out once, but my only major complaint with this game is that it is quite short. But it is definitely worth playing if you like point and click puzzle games.

												Immediately after playing The Walking Dead Season 1, I've stumbled upon Telltale's Puzzle Agent. Done in collaboration with Oscar nominated cartoonist Graham Annable, Puzzle Agent is great looking puzzle adventure game.  There are two aspects to Puzzle Agent. First is story and atmosphere. Dark, twisted humor and eerie characters will immediately remind you of Twin Peaks and other Lynch's works. Although the animation is crude (on purpose) and the whole style might belong in children's books, the atmosphere is horrific in all the right ways.   You are Agent Tethers of US Department of Puzzle Research. Tethers arrives to small, isolated town of Scoggins where nothing is what it seems and myths are colliding with reality. You will move around and experience the wild story by clicking on objects and talking with people. There are no multi branching dialogues and you may skip most of them, but that would be such a shame.  When it comes to puzzles, they're gradually getting more and more difficult, although never impossible to crack. Various types of puzzles are contained within Puzzle Agent: visual, mathematical and logical are all in there. Players need to complete 24 puzzles to complete the game, but at least 10 optional puzzles are available. Game also has a great hint system.  Puzzle Agent is truly a great indie game all lovers of wacky cartoon style, David Lynch, eerie atmosphere and puzzling will learn to love. ***Hey, you've liked this review? Hated it? 												Puzzle agent is a light adventure/puzzle game with a lot of charm and some imaginative puzzles, based upon the work by Graham Annable (which I was entirely unfamiliar with when I played the game)Graphics & SoundPuzzle agent has a very distinct art style, one that I guess is a bit of a love it or hate it kind of deal. It's very consistent though, everything looks like it belongs in the world, and nothing looks out of place. Personally, I found the game to be nice looking, in its own peculiar way.The sound design also works well with what the game tries to be. The voice actors do a good job at portraying the different characters, and while there are no Oscar winning performances here, it works well. The voice acting also helps lend the game a lot of personality, which makes it memorable for more than just its puzzles.Story & settingIn Puzzle Agent you play as agent Nelson Tethers, who works at the US department of Puzzle research. There are trouble in the small town of Scoggins and their eraser factory, which supplies erasers to the White House. Thus your job is of utmost importance to the safety of the country.Scoggins is a peculiar place. Everyone is obsessed with puzzles, and not only that, everyone is also a bit Norwegian. Your job is to find out what is going on, and why there are pointy red hats seen everywhere.To make matters worse, the entire city is out of chewing gums, something that agent Tethers need in order to focus on his puzzles. This ties in directly with the games hint system, if you spend some of the gum you have in you've picked up you get a hint for whatever puzzle you're working on.GameplayGameplay is mostly straight forward. You click on objects like in a point & click adventure game, gather talk to people, and quite often you're given a puzzle. These puzzles don't fit in as well with the world as something in say Syberia or The Longest Journey, but are their own self contained little entities. This does allow the game designers to constantly mix things up with new and interesting puzzles, but at the expense of some immersion. If you've ever played a Professor Layton game, you'll feel right at home here, the puzzles are handled in a similar way. And the vast majority of the puzzles are fun to solve. Puzzle Agent is not a particularly lengthy game. The game can easily be beaten in less than 3h if you're comfortable with solving logical puzzles.Final thoughtsPuzzle agent is an excellent little puzzle game with a really fun story, and some well thought out puzzles. At a base price of 5€, it's hard to not recommend this game, despite its short length.

												Puzzle Agent is a casual little 3-4 hour puzzle game that remains reasonably entertaining throughout, though it's a tepid sort of entertaining that I can't really recommend.The puzzles themselves aren't very well scaled in difficulty, with both easy and trickier ones mixed together throughout, though none of them could be called challenging. Certain puzzles reminded me of SAT logic questions back from my high school days, so I suppose it takes a certain kind of person to enjoy them. I recommend using a notepad, since many puzzles with a logical process of elimination or others with more visual elements are made easier this way. The puzzles are also graphically unappealing - the in-game story / adventure sections give way to single static screens for each puzzle, without any moving elements (uncontrolled by the player at least) and an overall board game-type look.The biggest problem though is that the puzzle design just isn't very good. A few puzzles have a set of "rules" that must be followed to successfully complete them. Unfortunately, certain rules are vague and open to different interpretations, and others are entirely ommitted (unintentionally) and must be discovered by submitting an incorrect answer. An example of this would be a sequence of platform movements to build a bridge - ommitted rules include "all platforms move at the same time", and "platforms stop moving once they reach a destination". I know that's a bit hard to visualize if you haven't played the game, but I felt like I should give an example.In at least two specific puzzles I can remember, I submitted absolutely correct answers that followed every rule provided by the game, but were not the solutions the game was looking for. Those are disappointing oversights for a game built around only a handful of puzzles (just over 30). And there are 4 or 5 puzzles that involve assembling objects like a jigsaw - these can all be easily and quickly cheated without any effort by dragging a piece around the screen until it snaps together with another, and repeating until the puzzle builds itself.Puzzle Agent's shortcomings in puzzle-solving are offset by the fact that there is no real penalty for wrong answers. They reduce your score, but perfect scores are not rewarded by anything at all, so no one save the most addictive completionists will care.What elevates the game from "bad" is the story, which I found charming and mysterious. I'm a sucker for the Mountain Town with a Secret kind of vibe. The voice acting isn't better than okay, and the game also struggles with its tone - it jumps from dark and mysterious to silly and unbelievable - but it's still sort of fun.(At one point you distract someone pointing a gun at you by throwing a crossword puzzle at him, and he just can't help himself from filling out a crossword puzzle, can he? It's looney, I guess.)Fair warning though: the game ends on a cliffhanger without revealing its mysteries, so it feels more like Episode 1 to the sequel's Episode 2 rather than a self-contained full story.Another warning: Puzzle Agent 2 does not work on any Mac OSX released since mid-2013. This is not a problem that is likely to be fixed, so if you're strictly a Mac user, DO NOT invest any time into this game, since you will be left without the story's conclusion. This is another example of the Steam Store's lack of quality control, and Mac's terrible habit of compatibility issues with each new OSX release. Who's to blame but everybody I suppose?So in short, there's nothing really *bad* about this game, but it's not great. Definitely not worth a full-price purchase, but if picked up on mega sale, it makes for a reasonable distraction when you have nothing to do.5/10

Is there really a need, for god's sake? Every single conversation is animated, and takes a long time to get through. You absolutely cannot fast forward anything. (See point #2 below.) No way to fast forward dialogue without missing out on reading it The way dialogues take place in this game is like this: as every character speaks, a text bubble appears, and the text only displays as they speak, and not at once. Now, if you try to make the dialogue go faster, clicking just causes the entire text bubble to disappear, instead of making the remaining undisplayed text appear! How stupid is that?! I wouldn't mind so much if characters said important things with every speech bubble, but most of the time the text is extraneous, so you are forced to sit through tons of worthless dialogue before you can finally glean the important stuff. Puzzles are way too simple E.g. Put fragments of a torn picture together. And said fragments are very big, not small or complicated in the least. E.g. Click on squares to rotate them until they all face the correct way, forming a complete picture. Puzzles are misleading E.g. One puzzle said you would find a "hidden object" once you rotated the squares correctly to form the correct picture. There was no such "hidden object". Some puzzle instructions are very poor E.g. In one puzzle, you must place logs to make your character go the correct way. You are supposed to "pass 2 traffic lights" along the way. Now, I had no idea the 2 traffic lights were "passable" (i.e. your character could go through them), as opposed to being an obstacle on the board. Also, when you say "pass", do you mean you need to pass them on the left? Or right? Or through them (which was the intention)? As a result of the complete ambiguity, this puzzle had to be attempted a 2nd time before I finally understood what the game wanted. Way too much hand-holding in the beginning At the start of the game, instead of asking you if you want a tutorial or stuff, the game just SPECIFICALLY TELLS YOU WHAT TO DO next. As in, "talk to man", "enter hotel", etc. This went on for quite a while, until I thought the entire game would be like this.  No free exploration + no real choice If you're looking for a true adventure game where you can freely roam and check out objects in your own time, this is not that game. It is extremely linear, and most of the time you are implicitly told what to do or where to go next. So it plays out more like an interactive novel, only with so-called puzzles to solve along the way.ConclusionBased on the interface, excessive hand-holding, extremely slow dialogue & game pace, way too easy puzzles, etc, I have to conclude that this game is more for kids. As an adult, I just did not have the patience to deal with the horrible mechanics of the text bubbles in particular. I cannot for the life of me understand why clicking to fast forward wouldn't just show you all the text immediately rather than make it completely disappear. This was extremely frustrating and irritating and I could not see myself sitting through this game waiting for countless text bubbles to disappear.

												Was Puzzle Agent really made by the same company that brought us the much acclaimed Walking Dead? So, just like Professor Layton, which inspired this game, we have an adventure game on our hands where the classical adventure game mechanisms (environmental puzzles, item combination, branching dialogues) have been replaced by logic puzzles, the vast majority of which have no actual tie to the story whatsoever.The main problem with Puzzle Agent is that the puzzles aren't very good. Of the 37 that I've solved, I'd say only 5 to 8 were both fresh and challenging. The rest were either much too easy or felt really, really old. Far too many puzzles involved rotating tiles on a grid to form a loopy picture, or jigsaws of some sort. These were really not fun at all (but easy so at least you could get rid of most of them fast). When there was difficulty involved, it's unfortunately often because of poorly written instructions.Another problem is the humour. It works occasionally. But 50% of the "jokes" involve characters staring at the main protagonist in silence when asked questions. Let me underline that: 50%!!! It's not exactly hilarious the first time, and it becomes completely, utterly stupid after a while.It's not all bad. Like I said, a small number of puzzles were inventive. I also kind of liked the story (bar the humour), although I wish one shouldn't have to play the second episode to see the conclusion. (I won't!). The art style is pleasant, but inconsistent, at least on PC. It's mostly "blurred/irregular lines", like in some comics, but then some stuff gets drawn with geometric precision, causing a very unaesthetic clash of styles. The animation is also very stiff, but I think that's on purpose. It may or may not bother you.If there is one thing that I feel is wholly praise-worthy, it's the audio department. I loved the music. It sounds like a subtler version of Danny Elfman and admirably suits the story. And while the dialogues won't leave a lasting impression because of average to poor writing, the voice actors themselves made a commendably good job despite the material at hand.Now, I'll be honest: I don't think puzzle adventure games have a bright future. It's a genre that is great in theory, but never works in practice. You'll always get more, better designed puzzles in a magazine (like GAMES Magazine) and the stories in those video games will always feel tacked on. I didn't like Puzzle Agent, but I didn't like Professor Layton either. However, if you absolutely must play a game from that narrow genre, well, Layton has better puzzles.

												What do you get when you combine the adventure and puzzle gameplay of Professor Layton with a surreal world heavily inspired by Twin Peaks? You get Puzzle Agent, a Telltale adventure game made in collaboration with Canadian Artist Graham Annable.You play as Nelson Tethers, FBI Agent in the department of Puzzle Research who is assigned to his first field mission of getting an eraser factory re-opened. Said factory is located in the small town of Scoggins, Minnesota where you very quickly figure out not everything is as it seems. As said before the plot takes heavy influences from David Lynch and Kubrick, creepy surreal happenings mixed with just the right amount of humor make it a very interesting plot, leaving you guessing as to just what is going on.If you have ever played a Professor Layton game then you will feel right at home here, if not then I shall explain. The main gameplay is divided into two parts, you have your normal point and click adventure gameplay where you talk to locals and learn more to uncover the mystery, and the puzzles where you will be tasked with solving something for someone or just to get past something and rather than the usual point and click style of searching around for items in an inventory it just pops up another screen and gives you a puzzle all laid out for you to solve ranging from putting together pieces of something, rotating blocks to line up pipes, finding differences between pictures, and more.Now just looking at all of this you would think I could recommend this game wholeheartedly. However, for every nice thing I have to say about it I have just as many problems.While the story has wonderful setup and great dialogue, including horror elements which I was not at all expecting, it sadly feels incomplete. I won’t spoil the story but very little actually gets explained which leaves you to question just what happened and in some way it feels as if Puzzle Agent 1 and 2 should have just been one full game, but considering this is a Telltale game that does not surprise me.There are only about thirty puzzles overall in this game which is not a lot and while some are clever and tricky, there will be a few times you are getting a puzzle wrong because the instructions themselves are incredibly vague as to what you need to do sometimes and on the flip side there will be some puzzles that you could complete while being half asleep with nearly no brain function, trust me on that. Because of how few puzzles there are in the game it is also short, my runtime is around three hours and that is with me messing around or leaving the game paused a bitOverall I wish Steam let me pick a middle ground between recommended and not, because it is a bit of a tossup either way. However in spite of the issues I had with the game and in light of its low price and thinking of it as the first ‘episode’ of the Puzzle Agent series I recommend it to adventure and puzzle game fans, and if you love the likes of Twin Peaks as I do you will greatly enjoy the little nods and references sprinkled throughout.

Even though the game is shorter than average, what it lacks in quality, makes up in quality.First off, Puzzle Agent is set in the Grickle universe, made by Graham Annable. Grickle is based in a very surreal setting of the supernatural and downright bizarre, so those already familiar with his works will find themes in this game familiar.The puzzles in Puzzle Agent can be a mixed bag of easy and difficult, though are pretty consistent with the easier puzzles being found near the beginning of the game and the more difficult ones being found near the end of the game. Puzzle Agent also comes with an interesting help system; Nelson finds it easier to solve puzzles when chewing gum, but can only chew on three pieces of gum per puzzle, one hint given per piece of gum chewed. The hints given are usually in the form of clue > how to work out the solution > here's the answer. Thanks to this helpful hint system, I didn't have to look online for any guides when I was completely stuck.I can't talk about the plot of Puzzle Agent without spoiling anything as everything kicks off right from the getgo, but if you are interested in finding out what happens, you can watch Ross Scott's Game Dungeon episode here.Do I recommend buying Puzzle Agent? Yes, especially if you're in the mood for a small, charming puzzle game. For NZD$5.99, I'd wait for a sale for when this game is $2 - $3 before buying it.

Puzzle Agent is charming, but also weird and dark puzzle adventure game. Overall very recommendable.Graphics: The artstyle is very delightful and unique in its own way. It's like a pencil drawing come to life. At larger resolutions it does take some getting used to. Additionally, the animations consist of very little frames, making movements very abrupt.Sound, Music & Voice: The soundquality and music were at an acceptable, but not very impressive level. The main character's narration was well done and fits his character. However, I felt that besides him the other voice actors tried to paint a too stereotypical picture and subsequently found the narration besides the protagonist subpar.Gameplay & Story: There are around 37 puzzles, which consist of many different mini-games. There is rarely a repeating puzzle design, which prevents the many puzzles from becoming tedious, but also makes it difficult to improve over the course of the game.The puzzles usually advance the story a bit, before you are tasked again with the next puzzle.Definitely the most enjoyable was the weird setting of the game, where the protagonist belongs to the FBI Department of Puzzle Research and is tasked to investigate an accident at an eraser factory in a village with people who are obsessed with puzzles (and little gnomes).It takes about 3 - 4 hours to finish this game. Beware of unexpected, dark story twists!Funfactor: I found the game to be more enjoyable than expected, mainly due to the charming and amusing setting. The puzzles were mostly on the easy side, although due to the many different types of puzzles, not all were intuitive and well-explained. Some might cause you a bit of frustration. Exceedingly and unnecessary long were the resolutions of each puzzle, taking 20 (!) unskippable seconds. Verdict: Wait for a sale. Puzzle Agent is charming and often enjoyable story puzzler, but inconsistent puzzle design and long waiting times prevent it from being an outstanding one.

												Telltale Games has drastically risen in popularity over the last few years thanks to their incredible work on games such as The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us and Game of Thrones. I haven't the faintest clue of their past work except for this little gem, Puzzle Agent. If the name didn't give it away already, this title focuses on solving puzzles to drive the story. You're an FBI agent in a little town in Minnesota trying to uncover the mystery of a recent accident at the local eraser factory. The plot is odd but amusing. I found myself smirking in amusement and sheer confusion as to what was happening at some points. I feel that, for me, this was the driving force of Puzzle Agent. The peculiarity of the plot continually peaked my curiosity as I solved puzzles. I wanted to know more about the bizarre going ons of this small Minnesota town. The puzzles themselves are rather straightforward, save for a couple that had me stumped. Each puzzle is graded as it's solved--taking how many attempts and hints it took for you to solve it. I found the majority of the brain teasers to be enjoyable and at a pretty comfortable level. The few I had difficulty with I can blame on the presentation of the puzzles. You're given rules to each puzzle before you try your hand at it, and sometimes the developers did poorly in explaining how it was supposed to work. This happens especially near the end of the game when you face your greatest challenges. Overall, I didn't find it overly frustrating. That's not to say that no puzzles got the better of me because of their clever designs, because there were a few that did. Those were my favorite because it made me smile when I realized what I had missed. The game ends on a cliffhanger and I find myself debating if I want the second instalment of the series. I can tell you now that I will someday. It's only a matter of time before my curiousity of what the hell was going on in that town gets the better of me. This game is for puzzle lovers only. If you enjoy an intellectual challenge then I can certainly recommend this one to you--but only when it's on sale.

Puzzle Agent is charming, but also weird and dark puzzle adventure game. Overall very recommendable.Graphics: The artstyle is very delightful and unique in its own way. It's like a pencil drawing come to life. At larger resolutions it does take some getting used to. Additionally, the animations consist of very little frames, making movements very abrupt.Sound, Music & Voice: The soundquality and music were at an acceptable, but not very impressive level. The main character's narration was well done and fits his character. However, I felt that besides him the other voice actors tried to paint a too stereotypical picture and subsequently found the narration besides the protagonist subpar.Gameplay & Story: There are around 37 puzzles, which consist of many different mini-games. There is rarely a repeating puzzle design, which prevents the many puzzles from becoming tedious, but also makes it difficult to improve over the course of the game.The puzzles usually advance the story a bit, before you are tasked again with the next puzzle.Definitely the most enjoyable was the weird setting of the game, where the protagonist belongs to the FBI Department of Puzzle Research and is tasked to investigate an accident at an eraser factory in a village with people who are obsessed with puzzles (and little gnomes).It takes about 3 - 4 hours to finish this game. Beware of unexpected, dark story twists!Funfactor: I found the game to be more enjoyable than expected, mainly due to the charming and amusing setting. The puzzles were mostly on the easy side, although due to the many different types of puzzles, not all were intuitive and well-explained. Some might cause you a bit of frustration. Exceedingly and unnecessary long were the resolutions of each puzzle, taking 20 (!) unskippable seconds. Verdict: Wait for a sale. Puzzle Agent is charming and often enjoyable story puzzler, but inconsistent puzzle design and long waiting times prevent it from being an outstanding one.

												I just played through this game start to finish in four hours and here are my thoughts.Puzzle agent has the potential to be a good game but falls short. I started playing and found certain dialogue genuinely funny but as the story progressed and became more ridiculous I lost complete interest in the story itself. Now I'm not against a 'random' or 'quirky' storyline, in fact there are many games that have thrived under that direction - however these stories work because you are invested in the characters and want to see them develop regardless of how outlandish the story may seem. Just for example - there is a cutscene where you are carried off into the woods by gnomes and wake up in a space shuttle in zero gravity where you need to solve a puzzle to get out, once you solve the puzzle you wake up in the lodge. That's it - there is no explanation given as to why you were there and it is literally never addressed again. I was thinking - are you trying to be random? funny?? Oh and before you go there this isn't a case of 'it was all just a dream'. Apart from the random story line this game has provided me with what is possibly the most unsatisfying ending I've ever experienced in a game. The ending was so frustrating that it may have encourage me to purchase puzzle agent 2 just to see what happens but because I wasn't at all invested in the lead character (heck I've already forgotten his name) lets call him detective mcgee that I wouldn't play puzzle agent 2 even if it promised a satisfying conclusion.That all being said, this is a puzzle game which means that the puzzles should be worth while. Yes and no. The original puzzles are clever and original - however they tend to repeat themselves and the final three puzzles of the game are hilariously easy. Also there is one particular puzzle that is unclear and could be interpreted several different ways.So to conclude I would only recommend this game if you are a serious fan of puzzle games - if not go pick up a copy of Lyne for a dollar more and focus more on the puzzles than any actual story.3/10

												This game is very... fine. I have a lot of small gripes about it but they're mostly inconsequential in the end, it's a decent adventure game and it's a decent story with decent puzzles. But it never goes beyond decent. I'm fine with the art style for the most part but when the images are blown up to large proportions they look very blurry and ugly. Some of the puzzles are vague or give vague instructions, resulting in either the need for a hint or the solution being marked as wrong because of the missing information. There's a weird awkward pause after dialogue ends quite frequently that feels... off. The characters just stand there unmoving for a second or two. The game's pretty short, too, completed in around three hours without any difficulty. There's never any mystery where to go, the game always guides you. The endgame feels like it just... happens. There's a small puzzle gauntlet and a non-ending that doesn't resolve any of the game's mysteries. I figure the second game will do so, but... don't. Keep your games self-contained, PLEASE. I have the second game already so I'll probably just play it soon and all but yeah... not a good way to end a game. Also plot-wise there's a point where you're forced to walk into an obvious trap without questioning a thing, which is lazy writing if you ask me.Despite all my small gripes... it's fine overall. The puzzle variety is decent though some get repeated like three times in a game with only 37 puzzles, which is eehh. The puzzle design is for the most part decent, though fairly easy. The plot's fine except for the ending. There's a neat thing where your puzzles get interrupted a few times. The horror elements here are used pretty well. The art style is unique and works well enough. The voice acting's pretty good. I like this game, I don't love this game, it's not very expensive and you can get it on sale dirt-cheap, check it out if you want your puzzle fix with a side of mystery novel.

												Good premise, faulty execution.Yes, the plot is rather silly, and serves mainly to tie the puzzles together. But since you bought a game called Puzzle Agent, presumably you're mainly interested in the puzzles, so that's okay.Where the game fails is that too many of the puzzles are poorly described: either the rules, or the goals aren't clear. For instance, in one puzzle, you have to place tiles to form a path through a forest, to a goal, without meeting any monsters. Except that it's not enough that there be a monster-free path to the goal: none of the branches may lead to a monster, something that the game doesn't make clear.In another, you have terminals on a circuit board, and have to form an electrical connection between them. After banging my head against this puzzle for half an hour, I bought hints and learned that the electrical circuits already printed on the board were purely for decoration, and not part of the puzzle at all.With some additional playtesting, and tweaking of the puzzle descriptions, the game could be much better.

												Synopsis: You, an intellectual, solves the the puzzles they have on the back of kids menus around 37 times.Gameplay:If that synopsis somehow doesn't sound unappealing, you genuninely might enjoy this game. When I say, puzzles you find on the back of kids menus, I am not emblelishing anything whatsoever. This game features top down mazes, connect the dots, and that activity where you have to rotate the tiles of an image to fix it. It's a very casual title and accessible to pretty much anyone. You're given infinite time to solve each puzzle, you can use gum you find in game for hints if you find yourself stuck, and it actually does feel rewarding to solve some of the harder puzzles. The individual puzzles were the absolutely the main hook for playing Puzzle Agent through all the way, as redundant as that sounds. I should note however, being a telltale game, you also have to walk to each puzzle and sit through unskippable cutscenes.Story:That said, the overarching "puzzle" of what was happening to the main town in game was lacking, to the point where I wondered if someone just wrote the whole thing up as they went along and never looked back. Stories traditionally are supposed to keep the player hooked, especially for point and clicks. However, Puzzle Agent went for the classic "I'm not going address the main issues with this game here so please support us anyway and buy our new game, fallout 4," so I didn't get closure on most essential plot points. Occasionally purposeful loose ends that can be executed well enough, but in my opinion it just felt sloppy or unplanned for here. For reference and without "spoiling" anything, if you watch the store page trailer, that's all you find out in Puzzle Agent. The premise sounds intriguing, but that's all she wrote.Art:It is functional for the purposes of making on screen pixels resemble persons, places, and things. The artstyle is meant to resemble the stylings of Graham Annable's Grinkle cartoons, but the choppy animation and missing drawn frames loses most of its charm for me since this is a full fledged studio team working on this and not just one man. It was endearing for a little at the beginning, but once 5 minutes passed it felt just ok.Music:Ok. It's not a strong point of the game, but when music is drawn into focus to make scenes more alive it works well. When doing puzzles, the music becomes very soft and low to mask the fact that it obviously has to loop. It never became annoying for me.Recommendation:I'm not going to recommend this game because if you or a friend is a fan of this kind of gameplay, I would sooner recommend either buying a real life puzzle book for like a dollar or a harder puzzle game.

Professor Layton and the Uninspired Ripoff GameThis game blatantly rips off the Professor Layton series. If you're unfamiliar with those Nintendo (3)DS games, you play as professional puzzle expert who solves a mystery in a town filled with jerks who refuse to tell you anything until you've solved a puzzle or two for them. Oh, and you can buy up to three hints to help you with any puzzle, by spending some sort of token. (In Layton it's coins, here it's... wads of used gum. Don't ask.) Aside from the fact that Tethers doesn't have a rent boy "apprentice", the structure is exactly the same.The one thing that Puzzle Agent does better than Layton is atmosphere. The game is fully (and competently) voice acted, which adds a ton of personality that's missing from the Layton games (which only has brief voice acted cutscenes, because of the space restrictions of 3DS game carts). Puzzle Agent's setting is a mix of Fargo and Twin Peaks, instead of Layton's weird intensely-Japanese idealized version of 1930's Europe.Unfortunately, this game's puzzles are consistently... mediocre, which is a big problem in a puzzle game. Many don't make the details of the puzzle clear enough (FYI the arm wrestling contest was single elimination), and sometimes keys details are needlessly split between multiple screens. And the other BIG problem with the puzzles is that there's no way to make notes within the game! Sure, it wasn't too hard for me to use pen and paper to figure things out, but what if you're playing on a laptop on a plane? This is a BIG oversight.

												The following review is of my opinions and I understand that some people may disagree with some or all of them.Puzzle Agent is a nice little Tell Tale style game with quite a few puzzles and riddles to solve. There is no inventory or items to collect except for bits of chewing gum that you find scattered about randomly in most scenes. Each piece of gum collected allows you to use a hint during a puzzle or riddle. Puzzle and riddle difficulties range from simple to thought involved but definitely not impossible. Some do make you think a bit and may take a couple attempts and hints to get, but they are fun to solve.The comic sketch pencil outline graphics style suits the game really well. Animation is fairly basic and simple but again suits the game well. I like the style and actually feel that I enjoy this particular game more with this style compared to if it was done with lots of fancy animations and renderings. Game sound effects are pretty good for the game. The music theme is good, although there is repetitiveness I did not find it tiresome or annoying. I did turn it down to about 75%-80%, but this is a preference of mine in general for all games. The voices are well done and suited to the various characters.The story is amusing and has a few quirky and comical bits. The ending was a bit odd and quick. I kind of felt that it left me hanging as in to be continued or something but without the To Be Continued text, which is probably why there is a second game.The entire game took me about 4.5 hours to play including a few breaks and mid-afternoon snack. For myself I feel that this was an appropriate amount of time spent for the game. Some people may finish the game faster while other may take longer. This is a great little game to pass away an afternoon or evening, also probably good for streamers to play on those short streaming days who are looking for a quick and short game to play. 												Puzzle Agent is a basic linear adventure story, well drawn, well voiced, and well scripted, with the occasional traditional logic puzzle tossed in to break it up a bit. It is a visually pleasant piece and the story is enjoyable and a tad quirky. For the most part, I would recommend this game. I had fun. And really that's what it is all about- having fun. Something light, something quaint, something you can do in a night.My only three complaints were: 1. You run through the exact animation for every solution submission for every single puzzle. Your answer is "submitted" in an envelope (couple seconds), a rubber stamp tells you if you were correct or not (couple seconds), and in there somewhere it tells you how much money it cost the government (few seconds), and how many hints you used (couple seconds) and so on (seconds seconds seconds) until you get your score and ranking and are finally allowed to continue (more seconds). Those seconds really added up and after a few puzzles they began to really drag on me. Around puzzle 10 I decided to wisely use that time waiting for the animation to finish by doing other things. Like read War and Peace. Sing 99 Bottles of Beer on the Wall. Build a lifesize model of the Ark. Take a power nap. 2. The jigsaw puzzle based games had a tight snap, meaning I could grab one piece and kinda jiggle it around the other pieces and the puzzle would eventually put itself together in just a few seconds. I discovered this trick when I was frustratedly shoving a piece out of the way to get to a piece underneath, and the stupid piece  just kept getting connecting to other pieces and being more in the way until it just solved itself. This trick was also how I managed to solve the gear puzzle faster than the animation squence notifying me of my score. And I am not be sarcastic when I say that.3. However the other puzzles were also easy. Very easy. I did find a work around by drinking an intoxictating amount of alcohol but that probably isn't the best solution, nor even remotely advisable, for underaged players. If you don't mind only having a mild challenge or if you are newish to logic puzzles, then really the level of difficulty probably isn't going to be an issue for you at all.

												And excellent game with an interesting art style and a quirky story that is like a parody of an X-Files episode.  The puzzles aren't terribly difficult, but they will take time to solve, so don't be impatient.  Nothing like 7th Guest level of difficulty, this is clearly intended to be a more casual game.  Your character cannot die, so you should move around and check out every lead presented.  It is only at the end that you can mess up, and if you do, you will be given as many "do-overs" as are necessary to finish the game.  That last part is the only one that departs from thoughtful puzzles to pointless clicking, which is a bit irritating but not impossible to overcome.  My hope is that, eventually, they will release a third Puzzle Agent game.  Yes, it is that good.
